repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Goias State Highway Management
            Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Goias State Highway
            Management Project in Brazil were as follows: outcome was
            satisfactory; risk to development outcome was moderate; Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory; and borrower
            performance was moderately satisfactory. Lessons include:
            when road maintenance is decentralized to municipalities,
            special consideration needs to be given to fiscal
            sustainability; and outsourcing routine maintenance under
            performance-based contracts is practical and the PPAR shows
            it can lead to lower costs of maintenance; Designing project
            activities outside the direct area of interest and expertise
            of the implementing agency, such as strengthening
            environmental management through road projects, can be
            problematic, particularly when they are not effectively
            included in a development objective and supervised accordingly.

repnme.cdata!: Brazil - Goias State Highway Management Program

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for Brazil - Goias State Highway
            Management Program were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            borrower performance was satisfactory. Lessons learned from
            the project: it is important to factor in fiscal conditions
            to ensure successful project implementation. Broad
            consensus, government commitment and realistic targets are
            some of the elements that help to speed up institutional
            reforms. A necessary condition to succeed in the
            decentralization of municipal road maintenance to
            municipalities is to create a framework of positive
            incentives for both parties. There are certain elements that
            are likely to facilitate the successful implementation of an
            adaptable program loan approach.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Goias State Highway Management
            Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Goias State Highway Management
            Program Project will increase, restore, and maintain the
            main highway network, including highway sections linking
            agro-industrial centers to major highway, or multi-modal
            corridors, and, will strengthen the highway system
            management through private participation, administrative
            decentralization, and the establishment of public
            expenditure planning, management, and control systems. The
            components include: 1) highway rehabilitation, and
            resurfacing works, as well as safety, and environmental
            rehabilitation works of the State's paved network.
            Related engineering studies, designs, and environmental
            (EA), and social assessments (SA) will be financed under
            this component; 2) highway paving works of roads linking
            agro-industrial centers to major highway, or multi-modal
            corridors, and, includes as well related engineering
            studies, designs, and EA and SA. Works will include
            strengthening, and reconstruction of road structures, such
            as bridges; 3) technical assistance (TA), staff training,
            equipment, and software, to support the Transport and Public
            Works Agency of the State of Goias (AGETOP), and the State
            of Goias Infrastructure Secretariat (SEINFRA), initiate the
            decentralization of road maintenance to the municipalities;
            monitor the maintenance program on the main network;
            implement the administrative reorganization; and, strengthen
            planning, and management systems; 4) assistance to the
            State's Environmental Agency (AGMA) initiate, and
            consolidate the expansion program of the state's system
            of protected areas - SEAP - and, strengthen AGMA capacity to
            screen potential environmental impacts, and management
            plans; and, 5) support the State's structural reform
            program, through TA, in reviewing, preparing, and organizing
            the state regulatory agency - AGR.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Goias State Highway Management
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment (EA)
            contains seven volumes, i.e., the Executive Summary, Terms
            of Reference for the Environmental Impact Assessment, Road
            Sector Environmental Report, Public Consultations Manual,
            Synthesis on Environmental Studies for the State of Goias
            Road Network Improvement and Management Program,
            Environmental Regulations for Road Construction in Goias,
            and, Basic Guidelines regarding Involuntary Resettlement
            Policies, respectively. Nonetheless, both the road
            maintenance/rehabilitation, and paving components will focus
            on existing roads, thus only limited environmental impacts
            are expected, with no direct impacts on the habitat of
            indigenous populations, cultural heritage sites, or, human
            displacements. Limited environmental adversity, and
            mitigation measures directly address construction works: 1)
            To reduce disruption to land degradation, soil erosion, or
            drainage patterns, as a result of earthworks, adequate
            drainage, and appropriate size of culverts, and embankments
            will be provided. Ground leveling will restore quarries, to
            be replenished with organic soil, and vegetation, while,
            waste, or spoil will be disposed of in borrow pits. 2)
            Adequate engineering designs will address land degradation,
            and soil erosion, including installation of infiltration
            ditches, to capture silt, and pollutants. 3) Dust, and noise
            pollution will be reduced by the proper choice of equipment,
            by installing sound barriers, and by limiting construction
            works to daytime schedules only. Long-term adversities,
            i.e., air and water pollution, impacts on flora and fauna,
            and traffic safety are addressed in the Environmental
            Regulations for Road Construction (v. 6).

            pollution will be reduced by the proper choice of equipment,
            by installing sound barriers, and by limiting construction
            works to daytime schedules only. Long-term adversities,
            i.e., air and water pollution, impacts on flora and fauna,
            and traffic safety are addressed in the Environmental
            Regulations for Road Construction (v. 6).
